natural problem: An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. (These 27 are included in the 85 and 73 mentioned above.) What is the minimum number of employees that need to be hired?
natural solution: There are $85+73=158$ jobs to be done. $27$ people do two of the jobs, so that leaves $158 - 27\cdot 2 = 158-54 = 104$ jobs remaining. The remaining workers do one job each, so we need $27 + 104 = \boxed{131}$ workers.
We also might construct the Venn Diagram below.

We start in the middle of the diagram, with the 27 workers who do both: [asy] label("Water", (2,67)); label("Air", (80,67)); draw(Circle((30,45), 22)); draw(Circle((58, 45), 22)); label("27", (44, 45));

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes water_air :: nat and air :: nat and water :: nat
assumes h0 : "water = 85"
and h1 : "air = 73"
and h2 : "water_air = 27"
shows  "water + air - water_air = 131"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. (These 27 are included in the 85 and 73 mentioned above.) What is the minimum number of employees that need to be hired? The final Answer is 131
 ### Proof
 There are $85+73=158$ jobs to be done. $27$ people do two of the jobs, so that leaves $158 - 27\cdot 2 = 158-54 = 104$ jobs remaining. The remaining workers do one job each, so we need $27 + 104 = \boxed{131}$ workers.
 We also might construct the Venn Diagram below.
 We start in the middle of the diagram, with the 27 workers who do both: [asy] label("Water", (2,67)); label("Air", (80,67)); draw(Circle((30,45), 22)); draw(Circle((58, 45), 22)); label("27", (44, 45));
 label(scale(0.8)*"$85-27$",(28,58)); label(scale(0.8)*"$73-27$",(63,58)); [/asy] This gives us $27 + (73-27) + (85-27) = \boxed{131}$ workers total.
 *)

theorem
fixes water_air :: nat and air :: nat and water :: nat
assumes h0 : "water = 85"
and h1 : "air = 73"
and h2 : "water_air = 27"
shows  "water + air - water_air = 131"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If the weight of water is 85 units, the weight of air is 73 units and the weight of water and air combined is 27 units, what is the total weight of air and water when they are not combined? The final answer is 131 units.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes water_air :: "nat" and air :: "nat" and water :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "water_air = 27"
and h1 : "air = 73"
and h2 : "water = 85"
shows  "water + air - water_air = 131"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. (These 27 are included in the 85 and 73 mentioned above.) What is the minimum number of employees that need to be hired? The final Answer is 131
 ### Proof
 There are $85+73=158$ jobs to be done. $27$ people do two of the jobs, so that leaves $158 - 27\cdot 2 = 158-54 = 104$ jobs remaining. The remaining workers do one job each, so we need $27 + 104 = \boxed{131}$ workers.

 label(scale(0.8)*"$85-27$",(28,58)); label(scale(0.8)*"$73-27$",(63,58)); [/asy] This gives us $27 + (73-27) + (85-27) = \boxed{131}$ workers total.
 *)

theorem
fixes water_air :: "nat" and air :: "nat" and water :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "water_air = 27"
and h1 : "air = 73"
and h2 : "water = 85"
shows  "water + air - water_air = 131"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If the total of water and air is 27 units, air alone is 73 units, and water alone is 85 units, what is the total of water and air minus the combined water-air units? The final answer is 131 units.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total water air both :: nat
assumes h0 : "water = 85"
and h1 : "air = 73"
and h2 : "both = 27"
and h3 : "total = water + air - both"
shows  "total = 131"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. (These 27 are included in the 85 and 73 mentioned above.) What is the minimum number of employees that need to be hired? The final Answer is 131
 ### Proof
 There are $85+73=158$ jobs to be done. $27$ people do two of the jobs, so that leaves $158 - 27\cdot 2 = 158-54 = 104$ jobs remaining. The remaining workers do one job each, so we need $27 + 104 = \boxed{131}$ workers.
 We also might construct the Venn Diagram below.
 We start in the middle of the diagram, with the 27 workers who do both: [asy] label("Water", (2,67)); label("Air", (80,67)); draw(Circle((30,45), 22)); draw(Circle((58, 45), 22)); label("27", (44, 45));
 label(scale(0.8)*"$85-27$",(28,58)); label(scale(0.8)*"$73-27$",(63,58)); [/asy] This gives us $27 + (73-27) + (85-27) = \boxed{131}$ workers total.
 *)

theorem
fixes total water air both :: nat
assumes h0 : "water = 85"
and h1 : "air = 73"
and h2 : "both = 27"
and h3 : "total = water + air - both"
shows  "total = 131"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 85 animals that can live in water and 73 that can live in air. 27 of these animals can live both in water and in air. How many animals are there in total? The final answer is 131.

a_3.informal problem: If there are 85 water molecules, 73 air molecules, and 27 molecules that are both water and air, how many molecules are there in total excluding the overlap? The final answer is 131.

and h2 : "both = 27"
and h3 : "new_employees = water_monitor + air_monitor - both"
shows  "new_employees = 131"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. (These 27 are included in the 85 and 73 mentioned above.) What is the minimum number of employees that need to be hired? The final Answer is 131
 ### Proof

a_4.informal problem: In a company, there are 85 employees who monitor water, 73 who monitor air, and 27 who monitor both. How many new employees does the company need to hire so that each task has its own person? The final answer is 131.

shows  "water + air - both = 131"

(* ### Problem
 An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_employees water_pollution air_pollution both :: nat
assumes h0 : "water_pollution = 85"
and h1 : "air_pollution = 73"
and h2 : "both = 27"
and h3 : "water_pollution + air_pollution - both = total_employees"
shows  "total_employees = 131"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. (These 27 are included in the 85 and 73 mentioned above.) What is the minimum number of employees that need to be hired? The final Answer is 131
 ### Proof
 There are $85+73=158$ jobs to be done. $27$ people do two of the jobs, so that leaves $158 - 27\cdot 2 = 158-54 = 104$ jobs remaining. The remaining workers do one job each, so we need $27 + 104 = \boxed{131}$ workers.
 We also might construct the Venn Diagram below.
 We start in the middle of the diagram, with the 27 workers who do both: [asy] label("Water", (2,67)); label("Air", (80,67)); draw(Circle((30,45), 22)); draw(Circle((58, 45), 22)); label("27", (44, 45));

 *)

fixes total_employees water_pollution air_pollution both :: nat
assumes h0 : "water_pollution = 85"
and h1 : "air_pollution = 73"
and h2 : "both = 27"
and h3 : "water_pollution + air_pollution - both = total_employees"
shows  "total_employees = 131"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a company, there are 85 employees working on water pollution issues, 73 employees working on air pollution issues, and 27 employees working on both issues. Find the total number of employees in the company considering that no employee is working on any other issue. The final answer is 131.

a_8.informal problem: If there are 85 water molecules, 73 air molecules, and 27 molecules that are both water and air, what is the total number of unique molecules? The final answer is 131.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes water_emp air_emp both_emp total_emp :: nat
assumes h0 : "water_emp = 85"
and h1 : "air_emp = 73"
and h2 : "both_emp = 27"
and h3 : "total_emp = water_emp + air_emp - both_emp"
shows  "total_emp = 131"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An environmental agency needs to hire a number of new employees so that 85 of the new employees will be able to monitor water pollution, 73 of the new employees will be able to monitor air pollution, and exactly 27 of the new employees will be able to monitor both. (These 27 are included in the 85 and 73 mentioned above.) What is the minimum number of employees that need to be hired? The final Answer is 131
 ### Proof
 There are $85+73=158$ jobs to be done. $27$ people do two of the jobs, so that leaves $158 - 27\cdot 2 = 158-54 = 104$ jobs remaining. The remaining workers do one job each, so we need $27 + 104 = \boxed{131}$ workers.
 We also might construct the Venn Diagram below.
 We start in the middle of the diagram, with the 27 workers who do both: [asy] label("Water", (2,67)); label("Air", (80,67)); draw(Circle((30,45), 22)); draw(Circle((58, 45), 22)); label("27", (44, 45));

 *)

theorem
fixes water_emp air_emp both_emp total_emp :: nat
assumes h0 : "water_emp = 85"
and h1 : "air_emp = 73"
and h2 : "both_emp = 27"
and h3 : "total_emp = water_emp + air_emp - both_emp"
shows  "total_emp = 131"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A company has 85 employees working in its water department, 73 employees working in its air department, and 27 employees work in both departments. What is the total number of employees in the company? The final answer is 131.
